raw_comment: The first thing I notice is that the 15-24 year-olds in the majority of the countries surveyed responded in greater numbers that the world is getting better with every generation in comparison to people who are 40+ in their country. I also noticed that Indonesia overall has a much higher rating of people saying the world gets better with every generation and this was across the board for ages surveyed. I also observed that the closer each country's dot was to the black line, the more the two age groups agreed with the other. For example, Morocco, Nigeria, and India all show that these two groups have the relative same consensus. I saw that about 21,000 and up people have been interviewed in each country by phone. I wonder if certain areas of these countries have different overall opinions and if they contrast from those in different areas. Also, if the survey was conducted only by telephone it could impact the results of the people being surveyed if many people in a country do not have access to a phone. I think a good name for the graph would be: "The Older and Younger Generations Hope for the World"
ace_sentences: I notice a pattern in the survey results.
In most surveyed countries, many 15-24-year-olds say that the world is getting better with every generation.
In most surveyed countries, fewer people who are 40 years old or older say that the world is getting better with every generation.
Indonesia has a high rating for the statement that the world gets better with every generation.
In Indonesia, this high rating occurs for all surveyed age groups.
Each country has a dot in the graph.
The graph has a black line.
If a dot is close to the black line then the two age groups agree more.
Morocco is close to the black line.
Nigeria is close to the black line.
India is close to the black line.
In Morocco, the two age groups have almost the same opinion.
In Nigeria, the two age groups have almost the same opinion.
In India, the two age groups have almost the same opinion.
In each country, about 21000 people or more were interviewed by phone.
I wonder if some areas in a country have different opinions.
I wonder if opinions in some areas contrast with opinions in other areas.
The survey was conducted only by telephone.
If many people in a country do not have access to a phone then the survey results can be biased.
A good name for the graph is "The Older and Younger Generations Hope for the World".
